title: Nick Jonas Priyanka welcome baby girl 12 weeks early
story: Share this article The couple both agreed it's best to focus entirely on their future child when they do become parents.She added: 'I'm okay with that. We're both okay with that.'While the Baywatch star has always been all about the 'next job', these days she is 'craving family life'.She explained: 'My priority has always been the next job. I'm a very, very ambitious person. But I think the woman in me is craving balance.'I'm craving my family life. I'm craving being able to do things for the soul that I didn't do because I was just 'blinders on' and working.'Nick and Priyanka tied the knot in traditional Hindu and Christian ceremonies in 2018.

title: Great British Bake takes stage musical inspired beloved programme
story: Share this article Mr McKerrow said: 'This brand-new Bake-Off Musical has been a creative labour of love that has taken several years of painstaking development.'But thanks to Mark and his fantastic team of musical producers and writers, who remained passionately committed to the cause, we really hope that this musical version embraces the soulful warmth and humorous spirit of the television show.'And that it proves to be a real treat for all the family and anybody who comes.'We often say, 'love the bakers, love the baking!' Now it's time to love the singers, and love the songs!'The Great British Bake Off TV series is fronted by judges Paul Hollywood and Dame Prue Leith, with Matt Lucas and Noel Fielding as the presenters.

title: Imperial College scientists urge university not cancel founding father Thomas Huxley
story: Share this article  Prof Armand Leroi, an expert in evolutionary developmental biology at Imperial College, described the history group's suggestions as 'frankly shocking' and said many members of staff were 'outraged' - especially the biologists.He added: 'Huxley was such a champion of egalitarianism, of access to science, of working class education. These are all things he worked for tirelessly in his life.'By the standards of the day he was an extraordinarily enlightened man - he fought against the racist scientists of his day who were allied with slavery ideologues in the US. He should be seen in the context and the mood of his time.' Imperial College has been contacted by Mail Online for comment. Scientists unite to stop Imperial College cancelling biologist Thomas Huxley

title: surge in school applications to upgrade ventilation and outdoor play areas
story: Minister for Education Norma Foley  says the funding is being announced now to allow schools a good lead-in period to plan and deliver the projects this summer. Photograph: Dara Mac Donaill There has been a surge in applications from schools to upgrade their buildings with better ventilation and outdoor play areas, new figures show.Minister for Education Norma Foley has announced that 500 projects have been approved for upgrades worth €65 million under this year’s summer works scheme. This compares with a total of 275 approved projects last year at a cost of €31 million.Separately, the Department of Education has confirmed that Covid risk mitigation measures – such as wearing masks – are to remain in schools until at least the end of the midterm break on February 28th. They are due to be reviewed in advance of this date and any changes will be communicated before schools reopen.The summer works scheme, meanwhile, is designed to allow schools to carry out small and medium-scale building works that will improve and upgrade existing school buildings.Many of the projects this year include window replacements, improvement to yards and play areas, as well as new science labs, roofs, mechanical and electrical works.In a statement, Ms Foley said the funding was being announced now to allow schools a good lead-in period to plan and deliver the projects this summer.“School communities have done an exceptional job in adapting to the changes required to operate safely in a Covid-19 environment,” she said.“A key priority is to continue to support and sustain the operation of schools in this context. I am particularly pleased that the cohort of projects announced today include window improvementreplacement projects in schools which will assist in managing ventilation in these schools.”Outside play areasShe said improvements to external yards and play areas were key as the provision of “fun and engaging outside play areas” was equally important in helping students and young learners engage with each other in a Covid-19 environment.The funding is separate to last month’s decision to provide €62 million in minor works grants as part of additional pandemic-related supports.Under this programme, schools have flexibility on how they use funding to improve their premises including the purchase of high-efficiency particulate-absorbing filter (Hepa) machines if they are deemed necessary. A breakdown of the projects announced on Monday show the majority (309) are at primary level and involve mechanical works (89 schools), electrical works (65 schools), window projects (89 schools) and external yardsplay areas (64 schools).At second level (109 projects), upgrades include roof works (81 schools), mechanical works (34 schools), electrical works (12 schools), window projects (35 schools), science labs (23 schools) and yardsplay areas (five schools).Ms Foley said it was envisaged that the remaining categories of projects from the current multi-annual summer works scheme would be dealt with as part of next year’s summer works programme in 2023. Relevant schools will be notified towards the end of this year.The Minister added that a new multi-annual summer works scheme with a strong climate action aspect would be open for new applications in the first half of this year.Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreak

title: dublin city council to curb build to rent and small apartment developments
story: Lord Mayor of Dublin Alison Gilliland: The policy change aims to encourage “high-standard, long-term, secure and sustainable housing”. Photograph: Dara Mac DónaillCurbs on build-to-rent developments and studio and one-bedroom apartments are set to be introduced by Dublin City Council.The new Dublin City Development Plan aims to stop developers from building blocks with no homes for sale, and to restrict studio and one-bed apartments to a maximum of 30 per cent of the development.Build-to-rent schemes will also be restricted to specific parts of Dublin, including the inner city areas of “high-intensity employment” ie with more than 500 employees per hectare within 500m of major public transport interchanges and within identified Strategic Development Regeneration Zones.‘Critical mass’No housing schemes would be rental-only under the new plan. Build-to-rent schemes of more than 100 homes would have to have at least 40 per cent of properties available for sale. Build-to-rent schemes of fewer than 100 homes will generally not be permitted, as they would not have a “critical mass” to support good communal facilities.City planner John O’Hara said the policy changes are not a build-to-rent ban.“The draft development plan is predicated on the whole notion of neighbourhood-making and sustainable communities. What we are looking for is a tenure ersity across the spectrum. Build-to-rent has only emerged in the last three years, but it has largely displaced build-to sell altogether,” he said.Remote working“The message from the property industry is that this is going to sink the whole build-to-rent typology. That is not the intention – with 40 per cent build-to-buy, the majority is still build-to-rent.”The reduction in the number of studio and one-beds in all apartment schemes, from a 50 per cent to a 30 per cent maximum, in part reflected the trend towards more remote working where people were more likely to require an extra room in their apartment, Mr O’Hara said.Lord Mayor Alison Gilliland said the policy change aimed to foster “high-standard, long-term, secure and sustainable housing”.Submissions on the draft plan can be made until February 14th.

title: fantastic buzz in dublin city as restrictions end
story: Enda Keogh, owner of Peter’s pub in 1 Johnston Place, Dublin 2, said Saturday night was “very busy”.There has been “a fantastic buzz” in Dublin city over the weekend after the Taoiseach’s address to the nation, announcing that almost all Covid-19 restrictions would end. Paul Cadden, owner of the Saba restaurant group, said there was “great excitement among staff and customers on Friday when the news broke.”“People were wondering, is this really true? Everybody is just delighted to be back out, a lot of people were feeling like they weren’t allowed to be before,” he said.Saba restaurants were trading throughout the restrictions and the 8pm closing time, but it had been quiet. “Online bookings and the phone are a lot busier now with people booking for groups and parties. It gives us all great hope in the industry,” Mr Cadden said.Enda Keogh, owner of Peter’s pub, said Saturday night was “very busy”.“We’ve been lucky in that we were busy when we were open with the early closing time thanks to regulars but the huge thing for us now is not having to do the contact tracing and all the admin,” he said.“I’ve been here since I was a child, it’s a family business, and it was just soul destroying sending customers home at eight in the evening, so it’s great to go back to normal trading hours now.”In Smithfield at 3pm in the afternoon, three cafes had a wait time of more than twenty minutes to get a seat. One staff member said it had been “the busiest Sunday in a while,” and a woman having coffee with two friends said they had been “out the night before at a nightclub in town” and the group were “having a celebratory hangover lunch”.The Lighthouse cinema in Smithfield and the Irish Film Institute in Temple Bar were both “really busy” on Sunday with the extended opening hours.Ian Redmond of Tramline nightclub did not open like some other clubs on Saturday night, as breweries weren’t able to deliver on time with the short notice.“The orders went in on Friday and we’re getting deliveries tomorrow. We sold out 900 tickets in three hours for Monday night. It feels like Garth Brooks is coming to town or something,” he said.Clubs are unable to get their special exemptions for late night trading until the District Court resumes next week, but Mr Redmond had the idea to do a belated New Year’s Eve countdown celebration for those customers who may never have experienced that before.“Why wait another eleven and a half months to celebrate the New Year? We’ve ordered balloons and champagne and everything. It’s great, it’s really exciting,” he said.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: full public inquiry of covid 19 pandemic required says mary lou mcdonald
story: Mary Lou McDonald said that a public inquiry should be time bound and should look in particular at the experience of nursing homes in the first wave.  Photograph: Alan Betson  The Mary Lou McDonald has said a full public inquiry should be undertaken into the Covid-19 pandemic rather than having a review focused solely on the healthcare response. The Sinn Féin leader was speaking after the Sunday Times reported that Government leaders have decided not to have a commission of inquiry or Oireachtas committee examine how the State has handled the pandemic. It is instead planning to begin discussions shortly on the appointment of an expert group to review the matter.Minister for Health Stephen Donnelly said he would seek Government approval for a report into the handling of the pandemic by the health service. It is not what clear the scope of that report would be, and whether it would be public or published, although Mr Donnelly said it would also examine the future of public health in the country.“Neither of those will suffice,” Ms McDonald told RTÉ’s This Week programme. “We have argued for a public inquiry,” she said, adding that it should be time bound and should look in particular at the experience of nursing homes in the first wave. A Coalition spokesman said the programme for government had committed to “review and learn lessons” from the handling of the pandemic. “An evaluation of how the country managed this pandemic will focus on what can be learned in the event of future pandemics or public health emergencies, and for reform of the health service,” he said. “The form and appropriate time of any review is still to be decided by government, as we continue to deal with the threat of Covid-19.” A source indicated that the coalition’s desire is to keep focused on Covid-19 and that the form of any inquiry was still to be discussed by Government. They added it would likely include expertise from operational and clinical sides. Another source said there has not been much discussion about the format of an inquiry yet, but that they would favour a “public element”. Ms McDonald also called for a hybrid option for the Leaving Cert this year, saying students taking the exam had suffered disruption right across the cycle of their studies. “They will still have their masks on, will still be in cold classrooms with the windows open, so we’re not back (to normal) by any stretch.”Everything you need to know about the Covid-19 outbreakStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: maureen dowd goodbye andr%C3%A9 leon talley my glorious difficult friend
story: André Leon Talley in Durham, North Carolina, where he grew up, in December 2016. Photograph: Jeremy M LangeThe New York TimesAndré Leon Talley was not the easiest of friends. He could be demanding. And cutting. And moody.But he was the most glorious of friends. He was soigné, to use one of his favourite words, and he had éclat, to use another. He was a true icon, prowling the world in search of glamour and beauty, disdaining “dreckitude”.“ ‘Dreckitude’ is the lowest point in the lowest ebb,” he once explained, adding, “ ‘Dreck’ is a total, total, total hot mess.”He was a hoarder who had all the most beautiful crystal and linens – not to mention Truman Capote’s old sofa – but he never entertained. He sometimes wondered why he could ensorcell so many with his wit and style but not have a lover.“I had dinners alone and I didn’t do lines of coke,” he told me about the Studio 54 era, when he worked for Andy Warhol. “I was not sexually promiscuous at all. I was fierce and smart and I did not exude that sexual energy. I wanted people to like me because I was smart, not for my black sex vibe!”André could be so hilarious that Tom Ford collected his friend’s emails and notes in a little book because they were “truly works of art”. “When he was excited, he was excited,” said Ford, who told me that he sometimes got a four-page letter on hotel stationery slipped under his door after a fashion show. “When he loved something, he loved it. When he hated something, he hated it. He was never boring.”I got to know André after he sent me a letter, in his big, loopy handwriting, about a column I wrote when my mom, who came from a family of Irish maids, died in 2005. He told me about his late grandmother in Durham, North Carolina, Bennie Davis, a maid for the men’s dormitory at Duke University, who raised him from the time he was a baby.His grandmother sparked some Proustian connections that would cause him problems later in life. He did not want to be the size of a “manatee”, he told me, but “the smell of a biscuit in butter and molasses” was his “opioid”, evoking his grandmother’s love.“So sad I got fat and had to resort to Scarlett curtains and portieres, disguised as caftans and djellabas!” he said. “But I soldier on. Hard work, though.”Ironed boxersHis grandmother taught him that poverty is not an impediment to panache she boiled his sheets white and ironed his boxer shorts and towels. Later, after Diana Vreeland plucked the tall, skinny black kid with the master’s in French literature from Brown University to be her unpaid assistant at the politan Museum Costume Institute, André understood completely when Vreeland ironed her dollar bills and tissues. Crispness was all.Indeed, it was one of the wrinkles in our relationship. I’m not an ironer. In fact, back in the 1970s, I threw out the family ironing board my mom had given me, in some sort of misguided feminist protest.When André would see me getting ready to go out in a wrinkled cocktail dress, he would fold his arms over his chest and order me to go change, or risk looking like “a roadshow Rita Hayworth”. Although that sounded good to me.Once, when we were going to the politan Opera, André looked at the bit of my sea foam vintage gown that was peeking out from under my coat. “Tulle,” he murmured ominously. “Blanche DuBois.”Another time, he took me to a White House brunch celebrating Barack Obama’s second inauguration. “This is your date?” Obama asked André, raising an eyebrow. But André didn’t care. He was focused on my footwear.“Rag &amp Bone bootees are not for going to the White House,” he instructed me when we were out of the receiving line. “They are for going to Starbucks. ”As André said about his advice, “I AM NEVER WRONG!” He advised all women to moisturise their skin as well as Melania Trump, although, increasingly appalled with the racism he saw in the Trump White House, he instructed me: “We are never to talk about her again. She is nouveau riche trash.”He loved Jackie Kennedy’s style but turned on her when he learned that she had snubbed Ann Lowe, the black designer of her wedding dress, calling Lowe simply “a coloured dressmaker”.“I don’t like Jackie O,” he said. “She is now Jackie No.”Not sweetWhen André was spending the night with me for that inaugural, he got the flu and ended up staying for five days. I cleared out of my bedroom and gave him my queen-size bed. He glowered at the closet that was too stuffed to close and barked at me to remove a hat from the wall, a broad-brim, pink-ribbon number that I’d worn to Easter Mass when I was little.“Your look is not sweet,” he bellowed. “It is equestrian S&ampM!”He missed his own tiger-stencilled sheets, and he called me Bad Nurse. He kept me running with his requests for chicken noodle soup, Georgetown Cupcakes, chocolate milk and turkey chilli.“Yes, I am difficult,” he said, “but I am loyal to a fault.”As his friend Diane von Furstenberg told me, when Vreeland’s eyesight failed her late in life, André went to that famous red apartment and read to her. His loyalty was not always returned by those he had assumed were his best friends in the throwaway world of fashion.“People turn on you in an eyelash blink,” he said to me, sadly.He described his sojourn leaving his size-18 Uggs beside my bed as “sheer joy and mayhem”, and he was right. We lounged in bed and watched old French movies and analysed the allure of French movie stars from the ’60s. (His favourite was Jeanne Moreau in Eva, where she flayed her lover with a riding crop.)One Christmas, to celebrate our love of movies, he gave me a special gift he’d gotten at auction: Joan Crawford’s sable coat, with “JC” embroidered inside. I didn’t put it on a wire hanger. – This article originally appeared in The New York TimesStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: inside number 10 defectors club
story: There are two words to describe what it feels like to cross the floor of the House of Commons according to defector Shaun Woodward: “Relief – and that it’s ghastly.”A little over two decades before Bury South MP Christian Wakeford jumped ship from the Conservative Party to Labour last week, Mr Woodward made the same journey, a process he found both more painful than he could have imagined and, in hindsight, always inevitable. Woodward quit after the Tory leadership under William (now Lord) Hague opposed plans to repeal Section 28, the rule prohibiting the “promotion” of homosexuality in public arenas including schools. Wakeford, a 37-year-old former insurance broker, who was elected as Conservative MP for Derby South in 2019, made his dramatic departure declaring Boris Johnson and his party incapable of providing leadership in the wake of the furore over parties at No 10.Whatever the motivation, nearly all those in the small defectors’ club of MPs say they have no regrets about breaking the ultimate political taboo.Westminster might love the drama of an MP crossing the floor, but what is the human impact on the “traitors” who abandon their tribe – and on the morale of those left behind? Can they ever find a home among politicians and activists who once saw them as the enemy, or are they always viewed with suspicion? Wakeford himself has said the decision to abandon Johnson’s party for that of Sir Keir Starmer was the most difficult of his life. Clearly shaken by the experience, he admitted to sleepless nights and stumbled over his new leader’s name in his first public event as a Labour MP, momentarily giving the impression he was now serving “Keir Llama”. For Woodward too, the decision was a traumatic one – “seismic,” he says - with his departure accelerated, as, allegedly, with Wakeford, by the Whips’ Office attempting to blackmail him into toeing the line.  “I just thought – this is horrible this is not why I came into politics. So I reached out to friends in the Labour Party and said: ‘I don’t think I am going to stay in the Conservative Party.’”“I am very conscious of the people I hurt. But I didn’t go because I would be well received, I went because I couldn’t possibly stay.”Baroness Nicholson, who as Emma Nicholson crossed the floor from the Conservatives to the Liberal Democrats in 1995, agrees: “I suddenly flipped,” she told Radio 4’s Today programme this week. “I was getting sick and tired of John Major’s vacillation on the European issue. I could suddenly take it no longer.“The worst thing about changing political parties is that you hurt people, and you hurt people who you love dearly, admire, respected, even fought with, but you hurt them very much indeed, and to live with that hurt is really, really difficult.”Like Woodward, who was dismayed by what he saw as the abandonment by Hague of One Nation Toryism, former Liverpool Wavertree MP Luciana Berger considers that her party left her, rather than the other way round. In 2019 she co-founded The Independent Group in response to what she viewed as a failure to act against anti-Semitism under Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership this later became a new political party, Change UK, before Berger eventually joined the Liberal Democrats.“It was horrific to leave my political home of 20 years,” she reflects, “but in my mind it didn’t in any way represent the values that led me to it in the first place, so I could no longer be a part of it.“I absolutely made the right decision and I don’t have any regrets and I would do it again.” Jumping ship used to be a far more common affair – Winston Churchill decamped from the Conservatives to the Liberal Party in 1904, not returning to the fold for two decades. But even then “ratting” was a high stakes game. When a group of Labour MPs resigned the whip to join Oswald Mosley’s fascist New Party in 1931, two quit after a day to become independents.In recent years, defecting has proven something of a kamikaze mission of the 23 MPs who crossed the floor in the last 30 years, all but four lost their seats at the next election, Berger among them. Of the four who survived, two – including Woodward – had been offered safer seats than those they had won under a different party’s banner.The only two to have triumphed again at the ballot box are Douglas Carswell and Mark Reckless, who quit the Conservatives for the UK Independent Party in 2014 crucially, both took the decision to resign as MPs and stand again in a by-election (Reckless, however, lost at the next general election).Carswell says the decision to fight a by-election was partly tactical, to put maximum pressure on then-prime minister David Cameron to hold a referendum on the question of Britain’s membership of the European Union, but also a matter of principle. Carswell’s defection was greeted relatively positively by both the voters and his party activists in his constituency of Clacton, with many in his local association following him to Ukip. To his surprise, most of his former Conservative colleagues in Parliament also remained on friendly terms.“I think they had respect for the fact that I had submitted myself to a by-election,” he says. “Had I not done that, they would have seen it as a case of getting elected under their colours then abandoning them.”That’s not to say that Carswell didn’t find the process emotional.“Anyone who is leaving one party for another is going to find difficulties. The only way to neutralise that is to resign and call a by-election.”Woodward, however, disagrees. “If you think that every time somebody crosses the floor there should be a by-election then Parliament should change the law. It shouldn’t be a reaction to one inidual’s actions. At the moment we still put the name of the candidate on the ballot paper – not the party.”Saying that, Woodward admits he felt far more comfortable in the Labour Party once he fought a general election in his new seat of St Helens. This, he says, helped him to get away from the disapproval of his former activists in his former constituency of true blue Whitney.Of Wakeford he says: “Actually, I think if he stood for a by-election, he’d probably win.” Additional reporting by Eleanor Steafel Rosa Prince is editor of The House magazineMore from NewsPrince Charles: Britain must restore its lost hedgerows that form a &#39vital part of the landscape&#39Magistrates adopt bricks and mortar approach to find more erse recruitsSue Gray to examine Boris Johnson’s official diary as part of ‘partygate’ probeNumber 10 police questioned by Sue Gray over Downing Street partiesCouple suing US state after being refused adoption services because they were JewishWhile Boris hangs on, poison is spreading through the Tory partyMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: bbc licence fees days could numbered two thirds britons want
story: Nearly two thirds of the public back the abolition of the BBC licence fee, as the vast majority claim it offers poor value for money, an exclusive poll has revealed.The survey of 2,488 people, conducted after the Government announced its plans to freeze the levy, showed overwhelming support for the Culture Secretary’s proposals to shake up BBC funding and to replace the fee with a voluntary subscription.Only 23 per cent disagreed when asked if the £159-a-year licence fee should be abolished and replaced with a voluntary subscription only paid if they watched BBC programmes, according to the survey by pollsters Find Out Now and Electoral Calculus.By contrast, 42 per cent agreed strongly that it should be scrapped and a further 21 per cent agreed “somewhat”. The remainder were undecided or did not have an opinion.An even larger proportion, 71 per cent, said that the fee was either very bad value or not enough value for money. Only 14 per cent said it was good or very good value for money, while 11 per cent thought the £159 was “about right”.Nadine Dorries confirmed last week that the licence fee will be frozen at the current rate of £159 until April 2024. The BBC had pleaded for the levy to rise in line with inflation, to allow it to compete with the likes of Netflix, under the new five-year settlement, which runs until 2027.However, the Culture Secretary has also hinted that the licence fee could be scrapped in five years. John Whittingdale, a former culture secretary, has proposed replacing the fee with a government grant, with viewers paying a voluntary subscription for entertainment and sport He said that the rollout of superfast broadband would ultimately allow viewers to “switch off” the BBC and pay only for programmes they wanted to view.Chris Holbrook, the chief executive of Find Out Now, said that streaming subscriptions appeared to have “tipped the balance against the BBC licence fee”.Martin Baxter, the chief executive of Electoral Calculus, said: “The public thinks the TV Licence is too high and is bad value for money. Most people would prefer a subscription-style arrangement instead of the current licence fee.”Younger viewers were more likely to say the BBC licence fee was very bad value than older people, a difference attributed to their wider use of Netflix and Amazon. Most 18- to 24-year-olds, 52 per cent, said it was very bad value versus 40 per cent of over 65s.There was also a political ide, with 60 per cent of Leave voters thinking that the BBC was very bad value for money versus 32 per cent of Remain voters. Half of Conservative voters said it was very bad value for money, as did 41 per cent of Labour voters. This compared with just 22 per cent of Liberal Democrats supporters.More than a third of respondents, 38 per cent, thought that the licence fee should be free, and two thirds said it should be no more than £100. Fewer than one person in every five believed it should be more than £150.There was also a class ide, with those in the AB social groups more likely to say that the corporation offered worse value for money.Of those in professional AB classes, 36 per cent said it offered very bad value compared with 43 per cent for C1 lower middle class households, 58 per cent for the C2 skilled working class and 61 per cent for DE working class and unemployed.A BBC spokesman said: “We trust longstanding, independent research, which shows the licence fee remains the preferred way of funding the BBC. We will continue to deliver brilliant content and work to provide great value to audiences across the UK. “We actively look forward to the national debate on the next Charter when, of course, all options should be considered.”More from NewsPrince Charles: Britain must restore its lost hedgerows that form a &#39vital part of the landscape&#39Magistrates adopt bricks and mortar approach to find more erse recruitsSue Gray to examine Boris Johnson’s official diary as part of ‘partygate’ probeNumber 10 police questioned by Sue Gray over Downing Street partiesCouple suing US state after being refused adoption services because they were JewishWhile Boris hangs on, poison is spreading through the Tory partyMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: convalescence making comeback not time
story: From the rhythms of our working lives and the places where we live, to the way we occupy our leisure hours and even shop for groceries – there is no aspect of our lives that has not been affected by the global pandemic.Some of these changes have been baleful: the damage to the arts, to the hospitality industry and education will not easily be repaired. But among the losses, some gains might be recorded.Among them is the idea of convalescence which, pre-pandemic, was widely regarded at best as a quaint leitmotif of 19th-century fiction at worst as a symptom of a feckless “sick note culture”.Between the 18th-century rise of spa towns across Europe and the NHS reforms of the mid-20th century (and beyond), the value of convalescence as a general benefit in policy terms has waxed and waned. But it is no accident that the rise of the novel coincides with the popularity of spa towns.From Jane Austen to Thomas Mann, the heightened emotions of places where people congregate to dodge mortality have always provided excellent subject matter for love stories, triumphant or tragic. The first novel set at the VivaMayr clinic’s post-Covid recovery programme (£2,700 per week, excluding accommodation) cannot be far off.Back in the prosaic present, GP Gavin Francis has published a reflection on Recovery: The Lost Art of Convalescence (Profile, £4.99). A return from illness to health, he argues, is a process that requires patience. There are limits to what doctors can do beyond offering guidance and encouragement through the process of recovery.It is a claim that defies our expectations of medical science we have acquired a habit of imagining our bodies as efficient machines, and are affronted when the machine issues urgent instructions to slow down. I have myself filed a column from an NHS hospital bed while attached to an IV drip.Some of these changes have been baleful: the damage to the arts, to the hospitality industry and education will not easily be repaired. But among the losses, some gains might be recorded.Among them is the idea of convalescence which, pre-pandemic, was widely regarded at best as a quaint leitmotif of 19th-century fiction at worst as a symptom of a feckless “sick note culture”.Between the 18th-century rise of spa towns across Europe and the NHS reforms of the mid-20th century (and beyond), the value of convalescence as a general benefit in policy terms has waxed and waned. But it is no accident that the rise of the novel coincides with the popularity of spa towns.From Jane Austen to Thomas Mann, the heightened emotions of places where people congregate to dodge mortality have always provided excellent subject matter for love stories, triumphant or tragic. The first novel set at the VivaMayr clinic’s post-Covid recovery programme (£2,700 per week, excluding accommodation) cannot be far off.Back in the prosaic present, GP Gavin Francis has published a reflection on Recovery: The Lost Art of Convalescence (Profile, £4.99). A return from illness to health, he argues, is a process that requires patience. There are limits to what doctors can do beyond offering guidance and encouragement through the process of recovery.It is a claim that defies our expectations of medical science we have acquired a habit of imagining our bodies as efficient machines, and are affronted when the machine issues urgent instructions to slow down. I have myself filed a column from an NHS hospital bed while attached to an IV drip.That is one of the sillier examples of presenteeism against which Francis argues. The Victorians and Edwardians lacked the benefits of wide-spectrum antibiotics and antidepressants, but (mostly thanks to the radical insights of Florence Nightingale), they understood the inestimable value of rest, fresh air, cleanliness and a nice view.More from NewsPrince Charles: Britain must restore its lost hedgerows that form a &#39vital part of the landscape&#39Magistrates adopt bricks and mortar approach to find more erse recruitsSue Gray to examine Boris Johnson’s official diary as part of ‘partygate’ probeNumber 10 police questioned by Sue Gray over Downing Street partiesCouple suing US state after being refused adoption services because they were JewishWhile Boris hangs on, poison is spreading through the Tory partyMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: silence putins imperialism exposes basic hypocrisy woke left
story: Beware of -isms. The term “imperialism” is terribly imprecise. Should we define it in Lenin’s terms as the “highest stage of capitalism”? But then much will depend on what we mean by capitalism, and empires have been around much longer than that. Woke enthusiasts for critical race theory may mention the world empire created by sixteenth-century Spain, without saying anything about the empires created by the Aztecs and the Incas on the backs of other native peoples of the Americas. Instead, the term “imperialism” has become attached to the empires created by Portugal, Spain, Holland, France and Britain, each of which had a very distinctive character.But imperialism seems to be on the way back. Over the last few centuries, Russia and China conquered peoples and carved out their borders in competition for the Eurasian landmass, and even now tensions occasionally erupt between them along the Amur River in western Siberia.Tension in and around the South China Sea is nothing new, either: in the fifteenth century the famous eunuch admiral Zheng He managed to bring Java to heel, and established a base at Melaka in what is now Malaysia. China’s “Belt and Road’ strategy frequently cites Zheng He’s voyages, and has resulted in the creation of naval bases at Gwadar and Djibouti, in waters where Zheng He sailed. Djibouti is highly desirable: it commands the straits leading into the Red Sea, and Gwadar in Pakistan, close to the Persian Gulf, is the intended terminus of a railway running all the way to Beijing.The echoes of the past are also becoming louder in eastern Europe. What nineteenth-century historians called the “Eastern Question” has been revived as Vladimir Putin sits tight in Crimea, contemplates an invasion of Ukraine and continues to offer support to the brutal regime in Belarus.Will a contrived border incident spark a war that results in the fall of Kyiv? That would echo the moment in 1939 when Germany and Russia suddenly became allies and decided to carve up Poland. The Russian claim to Ukraine is based on a particular reading of history where the foundation of a principality around Kyiv in the tenth century is seen as the birth of Mother Russia. In Soviet days it was considered unwise to emphasise that the founders of the principality were Viking warriors from the Baltic rather than Slavs.But where are the voices on the woke Left denouncing Putin’s attempt to sew back the disjointed fragments of the Soviet Union, something that can only be described as a new brand of imperialism? They only seem to care about imperialism if Britain or the like can be held responsible. If they think about the present day at all, it is to attack a country such as Israel. Those activists who argue that the West Bank settlements are illegal say nothing about the legality of the occupation of Crimea.We thought that we were living in an age when the forcible acquisition of territory based on obsolete historical claims should no longer be possible. The Baltic States are understandably nervous, particularly when Moscow makes noises about the Russian-speaking populations in their countries. Having travelled by road across the Baltic states three years ago, I wonder whether the surprising narrowness of the roads linking them is a deliberate defensive move intended to slow the advance of an invading army – if so, a wise precaution.To the woke, though, they are far-off countries of which they know nothing. As the world seems to be building up towards what has been described as potentially the gravest crisis since the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, far-Left activists gleefully concentrate on the evils of vanished empires created several centuries ago, and obstinately ignore one that is being recreated on Europe’s doorstep at this very moment.David Abulafia is professor of history at the University of CambridgeMore from NewsPrince Charles: Britain must restore its lost hedgerows that form a &#39vital part of the landscape&#39Magistrates adopt bricks and mortar approach to find more erse recruitsSue Gray to examine Boris Johnson’s official diary as part of ‘partygate’ probeNumber 10 police questioned by Sue Gray over Downing Street partiesCouple suing US state after being refused adoption services because they were JewishWhile Boris hangs on, poison is spreading through the Tory partyMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: women children first onto titanic lifeboats myth historian claims
story: It is one of the most enduring sentiments of a seemingly lost age of chivalry: “Women and children first.”However, the most famous application of that rule, on board the sinking Titanic, was in fact a myth, according to a historian.Claes-Goran Wetterholm, an author and expert on the doomed ocean liner, said it was “not true” that women and children survived thanks to the gallantry of men.Of the last survivors escaping on the final lifeboats leaving the starboard side of the ship, he said, the majority were men.Speaking to The Mail on Sunday’s You magazine to promote a new exhibition about the shipwreck in London’s Docklands, Mr Wetterholm said it is important to look again at the tragedy to “dispel some of the myths”.The exhibition will display 200 artefacts that belonged to passengers and crew on the Titanic, as well as recreate rooms on the ship to “submerge visitors in an unforgettable journey to the past”.Asked about the public obsession with the 1912 disaster, which still captures the public imagination 110 years on thanks to the blockbuster film starring Kate Winslet and Leonardo DiCaprio, Mr Wetterholm suggested there were still new stories worth telling.The Swedish curator of the exhibition told the magazine it is “important to look again at the tragedy and dispel some of the myths”, including the notion of “women and children first”.The order, which famously came from the captain, was interpreted differently by officers on different sides of the ship, he said.“While the story goes that those who survived were women and children, it’s not true: 323 men survived, 80 per cent of them got on lifeboats from the starboard side.“They survived because first officer William Murdoch, who evacuated that side, didn’t prevent them from getting in.“On the port side, second officer Charles Lightoller had the rule of women and children first and he took it literally.“One boat that could take 65 people rowed away with 28, leaving men behind. Over on the starboard side, it was a different story. On the last boats to leave, the majority were men.”Other common misconceptions include the nationality of passengers. According to Mr Wetterholm: “The fifth-largest passenger group were Arabs. They came from Syria and Lebanon in search of new lives, travelling by boat to join the Titanic at Cherbourg.”The claim follows research at Sweden’s Uppsala University in 2012, in which economists produced an 82-page study about the survivors of shipwrecks.It showed that captains and their crew are 18.7 per cent more likely to survive a sinking ship than their passengers, with “every man for himself” a more appropriate description than “women and children first”.The study of 18 maritime disasters from 1852 to 2011 showed that, of the 15,000 people who died, only 17.8 per cent of the women survived compared with 34.5 per cent of the men.Titanic: The Exhibition has been seen by three million people during its tour of museums, and is now at Dock X London where the 200 objects are on show in Britain for the first time. The  awarded the exhibition three stars.A separate book is also seeking to overturn the previous understanding that a wireless operator aboard the ship nearest to the sinking Titanic could have saved lives.Cyril Evans, who manned the telegraph equipment on the SS Californian 60 miles away from the Titanic, could not have saved the victims even if he had been awake to receive the distress calls, according to the authors.Mr Evans went to bed at 11.30pm on Apr 14 1912, with a US inquiry later finding that had he “remained a few minutes longer at his post”, the Californian “might have had the proud distinction of rescuing the lives of the passengers and crew”.“In short, had Evans received Titanic’s distress call, it would have already foundered and most of the people in the water would have died from cold shock and exposure before Californian arrived.”More from NewsPrince Charles: Britain must restore its lost hedgerows that form a &#39vital part of the landscape&#39Magistrates adopt bricks and mortar approach to find more erse recruitsSue Gray to examine Boris Johnson’s official diary as part of ‘partygate’ probeNumber 10 police questioned by Sue Gray over Downing Street partiesCouple suing US state after being refused adoption services because they were JewishWhile Boris hangs on, poison is spreading through the Tory partyMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: dominic raab plays down reports
story: Dominic Raab plays down reports mandatory NHS jabs could be delayed by  monthsAs it stands, in two weeks NHS workers will be expected to prove their vaccination status, with February  the last day they can book their jab" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _World-Wide-Rally-For-Freedom-London-Protest.jpg" width"" "" Protesters unhappy about compulsory vaccination for NHS workers Image: Getty ImagesByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Jan | comments Deputy Prime Minister Dominic Raab played down reports that mandatory jabs for NHS workers could be delayed by six months amid growing anger over the move. According to the , Boris Johnson is preparing to put back the April  deadline.As it stands, in two weeks NHS workers will be expected to prove their vaccination status, with February  the last day they can book their jab. On February , those without jabs will face dismissal warnings. They will then be asked to work their notice periods until March . More than , NHS staff are thought to not be jabbed, but many angry about threats to their jobs joined anti-vaxx protests over the weekend.Speaking on the BBC ’s Sunday Morning programme, Mr Raab said: “Nine out of  NHS staff have now come forward and had their vaccine. That is critically important. “I do think that we continue to call for thoseto come forward to be boosted or vaccinated before the deadline but I think ultimately we have to make sure that we don’t have people putting patients at riskthey are not vaccinated.“The deadline is there to protect the most vulnerable in our hospitals but we have got the resilience because we have got nearly , more doctors, nearly , more nurses than we did in .”Pat Cullen, chief executive of the Royal College of Nursing, said the deadline for mandatory jabs should be delayed or the policy will “backfire”. She said: “Nothing matters more to a nurse than caring for their patients safely. “Right now, our members are telling me they can’t always do that. “We are calling on the Government to recognise this risk and delay a move which by its own calculations looks to backfire.  “To dismiss valued nursing staff during this crisis would be an act of self-sabotage.” Danny Mortimer, deputy chief executive of the NHS Confederation, which represents organisations within the health service, said: “When we consulted our members, they told us that they would have preferred longer to implement the policy. “However they are working hard to prepare for the deadline and are continuing to focus on encouraging and persuading hesitant staff to get vaccinated to protect themselves and others. “We do have to acknowledge that as the deadline approaches some frontline staff will have to leave their present rolesthey continue to decline to be vaccinated.” Shadow attorney general Emily Thornberry said that a delay should be considered. Speaking on Sky News’s Trevor Phillips On Sunday, she said: “There is discussion about putting off the deadline, andwe are going to put off the deadline, then we need to work with the hospitals and with the trade union movement about how it is that we can convince as many people as possible who work within the health service to get themselves vaccinated. “Nobody who works in the National Health Service comes into the service for the money but in order to make sure they help others. “Arguments need to be put before them to say you are not helping others by not being vaccinated.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSBoris JohnsonHospitalsPoliticsCoronavirusCoronavirus vaccineDominic Raab MP" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: rishi sunak trying woo red
story: Rishi Sunak trying to woo Red Wall Tories who want to oust Boris JohnsonSunak, frequently tipped as favourite to replace the embattled premier, is said to have met with ringleaders of the so-called “pork pie plot” to jettison JohnsonThe Chancellor is reportedly wooing Red Wall Tories Image: Getty ImagesByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Jan | comments Rishi Sunak is reportedly wooing Red Wall Tory MPs who want to oust Boris Johnson as Prime Minister as part of a rumoured leadership bid.The Chancellor, who is frequently tipped as favourite to replace the embattled premier, is said to have met with ringleaders of the so-called “pork pie plot” to jettison Mr Johnson. It comes as the PM is braced for the publication of senior civil servant Sue Gray’s report into rule-busting parties at Downing Street during lockdown, with scores of MPs poised to turn against him. According to the Mail on Sunday, Mr Sunak, who has remained tight-lipped about his embattled boss, spoke with MPs and hinted at a timetable for launching a challenge.The Chancellor is thought to be in competition with Foreign Secretary Liz Truss for backers as leadership hopefuls aim to build support on the down-low. One MP told The Mail on Sunday: “My impression is that Liz wants to go for it now, while Rishi would prefer for all this fuss to die down and run in the summer.” Another source suggested the Chancellor made clear Red Wall MPs would have “unlimited” Treasury support. They added: “He didn’t mention the leadership, but he didn’t have to - he made clear that they would be safe in his hands.”Meanwhile, aides and ministers - including Transport Secretary Grant Shapps, who insiders say cancelled a rail visit in Manchester on Friday - have been drafted in to help Mr Johnson draw up a spreadsheet of wavering MPs.Shapps cancelled the visit on Friday but the visit was due to take place on Monday. A junior minister will be sent in his place and Shappsapos office say he is due at a Covid O meeting on international travel.It followed a devastating Prime Minister’s Questions for Boris Johnson in which former Tory Christian Wakeford dramatically defected to the Labour Party,. Ms Truss, meanwhile, is publicly throwing her weight behind Boris Johnson, but is said to have privately approached MPs sceptical about the PM. She said: “He is doing an excellent job. Britain was one of the first countries to roll out the Covid vaccine. “We’ve had a very successful booster programme. We’re now able to open up our economy... one of the fastest-growing economies in the G. “I want the Prime Minister to continue as long as possible in his job. He is doing a fantastic job. There is no leadership election.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON The TreasuryGrant ShappsLiz TrussBoris JohnsonPMQsCivil servantsPoliticsRishi Sunak" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: russia face severe consequences putin
story: Russia to face severe consequencesPutin installs puppet regime in UkraineThe Foreign Office last night took the unusual move of naming former Ukrainian MP Yevhen Murayev as a potential puppet leader who would run Ukraine. Image: REUTERSByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsDominic Raab has said Russia will face serious economic consequencesthey install a puppet regime in Ukraine. The Deputy Prime Minister and Justice Secretary said the UK will support the Ukraine to defend themselves. But said it would be extremely unlikelyfor British troops to be sent to Ukraine to physically bolster their defence. Last night Britain accused Vladimir Putin of plotting to install a puppet leader in Ukraine.The Foreign Office took the unusual step of naming former Ukrainian MP Yevhen Murayev as a potential Kremlin candidate who would run Ukraine.  Mr Raab told Sky Newsapos Trevor Philips on Sunday: Weaposre standing shoulder to shoulder saying there will be very serious consequencesRussia takes this move to try and invade and also install a puppet regime.Vadym Prystaiko Ukrainian ambassador to the UK said he believes Mr Putin is capable of installing a pro-Moscow leader in the country.I do believe that. Itaposs not the first time theyaposve tried to do that, he told Sky News and added Ukraine is prepared to fight back.Shadow Attorney General Emily Thornberry said Labour backs the Governmentaposs approach to Russian aggression. Ms Thornberry also called for the Government to utilise a “new generation of sanctions”, including investigating the “unexplained wealth” of Putin allies living in the UK. The unusual move from the Foreign Office came as Western allies stepped up warnings that Russia will pay a heavy pricethe estimated , troops massed on the border launch any kind of incursion into Ukraine.In a statement, Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said the Russian plotting showed the s to which the Kremlin was prepared go to undermine the government in Kyiv.“The information being released today shines a light on the extent of Russian activity designed to subvert Ukraine, and is an insight into Kremlin thinking,” she said.  “Russia must de-escalate, end its campaigns of aggression and disinformation, and pursue a path of diplomacy. “As the UK and our partners have said repeatedly, any Russian military incursion into Ukraine would be a massive strategic mistake with severe costs.” Foreign Secreary Liz Truss has previously warned Mr Putin he must “desist and step back” from war in Ukraine or risk being dragged into a prolonged conflict like the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. news politics senior-tory-says-mp-who-"Nusrat Ghani criticised for lame excuse by FabricantByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A senior Tory MP has said the former minister who claimed she was sacked for her Muslimness, is not obviously Muslim. Michael Fabricant MP for Lichfield in Staffordshire has said Nusrat Ghaniaposs accusation stinks and he believes the timing of her claim is interesting. Ms Ghani told the Sunday Times she was sacked as transport minister in  as a Government whip had said her faith was making colleagues uncomfortable. She considered quitting politics after the whip said her Muslimness was raised as an issue at a Downing Street meeting [in March ]. The whip also said her Muslim woman minister status was making colleagues feel uncomfortable, and questioned her loyalty to the Party. Since she spoke out on Saturday night, Downing Street hit back and claimed Boris Johnson had met with Ms Ghani after her claims and he encouraged her to make a formal complaint.Mr Fabricant told LBC that itaposs open season on the whips office but open season on Boris Johnson to get him to resign.Prejudice of any kind in modern Britain is pretty pathetic. It was pathetic  years ago, itaposs even more pathetic now when this sort of thing happens, he told Andrew Pierce on the radio station.But, you know, ministers they come and they go, sometimes itaposs because you want to refresh the ministerial team. Sometimes itaposs because they were useless sometimes because theyaposre just average and mediocre and you want to put somebody .I think the whole thing actually stinks. The accusation being made by Nus Ghani. I mean, I have to say that someone had said itaposs because sheaposs a Muslim. I mean, sheaposs hardly someone whoaposs obviously a Muslim. I had no idea what religion she is. Mr Fabricant then references the Labour MP Keith Vaz who is also of Asian descent and highlights that he was a Goan Christian. He has been cheerleading for the PM throughout partygate and as more and more scandal hits the Conservative party.Last week, Mr Fabricant claimed allegations of bullying and intimidation from the whips office was “nonsense”.“If I reported every time I had been threatened by a whip ora whip reported every time I had threatened them, the police wouldn’t have any time to conduct any other police work,” Mr Fabricant said. title: the world needs act now
story: The world needs to act now to drag m starving Afghans out of famine hellNo one outside the Taliban and their few friends disputes the need to impose sanctions. But it is in no one’s interest to leave hunger unaddressed, children unvaccinated and girls uneducated.Gordon Brown has warned the world it has just days to save m starving people living in Afghanistan Image: PAopinionByGordon Brown:,  Jan | commentsThere is no such thing as being too late. Preication, penny-pinching and a counterproductive ban on the flow of money that has prevented food supplies getting through, means the world is running out of time to stop a winter of starvation.The lives of  million Afghans are at risk.TV screens are full of scenes of emaciated families, dying children. And not just from famine. There are outbreaks of cholera and polio among children on top of Covid spreading among adults, % unvaccinated. All too slowly the world is waking up to the scale of the disaster. The UN has, thankfully, exempted money for food, health workers and teachers’ salaries from sanctions. But aid is not flowing through. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  The EU has donated million but only one quarter of the money needed for humanitarian aid has come forward. The World Bank has released the same sum but another .bn due to the troubled country remains in its US account. No one outside the Taliban and their few friends disputes the need to impose sanctions. But it is in no one’s interest to leave hunger unaddressed, children unvaccinated and girls uneducated. Previous initiatives have taken weeks and months. Butlives are to be saved three policy changes must be made in days,not hours. First, rich countries who have provided only a quarter of the .bn demanded by UN humanitarian chief Martin Grfith must now release this and ensure the World Bank frees up Afghan money it holds in trust. Second, we must empower the banking system so money can pay for supplies and the salaries of health workers, teachers and public servants who have been unpaid for months. Finally, Britain must call a pledging conference within days to secure the .bn needed to prevent famine. Forty countries joined the US-led coalition to fight the Afghan war. All should now contribute to saving lives amidst this uneasy peace. This weekend, a new Save the Children petition stresses there is not a moment to lose. My friend Malala Yousafzai, the Pakistan girl shot by the Taliban for supporting girls’ education, tells me she will be one of the first to sign.You can too – at savethechildren.org.uk Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON United NationsTalibanSave the ChildrenGordon BrownSunday Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: tories must u turn cost
story: Picture by Tim Merry" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" Diane Skidmore, who cannot afford to heat her home Image: Tim MerryopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Jan | commentsAble to afford boiling enough water for a single cuppa and switching on the immersion heater every other day despite freezing temperatures, D-Day veteran Jack Mortimer would be entitled to wonderour country is paying a debt of honour to the generation who kept Britain free. The terrible tales we tell today of people struggling to make ends meet are before April’s rocketing fuel bills start accelerate beyond recent rises, tightening the financial screw on people already struggling to stretch incomes to cover higher living costs. The year of the squeeze, , will force more folk to choose between eating and heating as poverty kills men and women in one of the earth’s richest countries. It doesn’t have to be this way. It’s a choice by the Conservative Government. And it’s a scandal that must be challenged, forcing the Tories into another U-turn – this time suspending VAT on energy bills, giving extra help to low earners and cancelling a hefty National Insurance tax rise.  Dignied, heroic Jack Mortimer and the others deserve our support. Out the bigots The sickening bigotry, prejudice and racism within the Conservative Party exposed by MP and sacked Minister Nusrat Ghani’s explosive claim her Muslim religion was why she was sacked from Boris Johnson’s Government is utterly repellent. Deep nauseating schisms exposed in the Tories by the unacceptable discrimination, Health and Education Secretaries Sajid Javid and Nadhim Zahawi speaking in support of Ghani while Downing Street and loyal backbencher Michael Fabricant add insults to injury, mustn’t be ignored.  This ugly scandal cannot be dealt with by the Conservative Party or Parliament. The Equality and Human Rights Commission must launch a formal inquiry into evidence that bigotry against Muslims is unlawfully polluting the governing party. Human writes Being able to read, write and count – what are confusingly known as the three Rs- are essential to live an enjoyable, interesting and rewarding le so the number of pupils going to secondary school struggling to understand even simple words and sentences is dispiriting. Improving the nation’s literacy so no child falls behind is a noble endeavour deserving more than lip service from politicians otherwise plunging disadvantaged families deeper into hardship. title: tory mp claims sacked muslimness
story: Tory MP claims she was sacked as her Muslimness was raised as an issue in No meetingNusrat Ghani MP for Wealden said she had to considershe wanted to continue being an MP because her faith was left shaken after the interaction. She was sacked as a transport minister in February Nusrat Ghani claimed she was told her Muslimness was raised as an issue during a meeting Image: PAByLucy MiddletonAssistant news editorAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  A Tory MP has claimed she was sacked from her ministerial post because of her Muslim faith. Nusrat Ghani, MP for Wealden was a transport minister from January  until February . The married mum became the first female MP to hold her Wealden seat in , winning with a majority of ,. But Ms Ghani considered quitting politics after her interaction with a Government whip who said her Muslimness was raised as an issue at a Downing Street meeting, she told the Sunday Times. The whip added her Muslim woman minister status was making colleagues feel uncomfortable, and questioned her loyalty to the Party. Ms Ghani, now vice-chairwoman of the powerful  Committee of Tory backbenchers told the newspaper: It was like being punched in the stomach. I felt humiliated and powerless. I was told... that there were concerns aposthat I wasnapost loyal to the party as I didnapost do enough to defend the party against Islamophobia allegationsapos. Ms Ghaniaposs claims relate to a meeting back in March . When she raised the issue, she was asked to use the formal complaints procedure but she declined to.Government Chief Whip Mark Spencer took to Twitter to identy himself as the person behind the MPaposs claims. In one now-deleted tweet, he wrote: To ensure other whips are not drawn into this matter, I am identying myself as the person Nusrat Ghani MP has made claims about this evening. These accusations are completely  and I consider them to be defamatory. I have never used those words attributed to me.  The conduct of the whipsapos office has come under intense scrutiny amid accusations they used intimidation and blackmail to pressure MPs seeking to oust Boris Johnson as Prime Minister.William Wragg, the senior Tory who first raised the issue and chairman of the Commons Public Administration and Constitutional Affairs Committee, praised Ghaniaposs courage in speaking out. He said: Nus is very brave to speak out. I was truly appalled to learn of her experience. She shows such strength and integrity supporting others. I am proud to have her as my friend and colleague. We must change things for the better. Wragg will be meeting a Scotland Yard detective in the House of Commons early next week to discuss his own claims. He told The Dailyhe would outline several examples of bullying and intimidation, in some cases involving public money. Fellow Tory MP and former minister Steve Baker also described Ghaniaposs treatment as completely intolerable and suggested her claims be investigated further. He tweeted: I value Nus Ghani as a great colleague and Iaposm appalled. We must get to the bottom of it. Cabinet Minister Nadhim Zahawi and senior Tory MP Tom Tugendhadt also backed Ms Ghani on Twitter, with Mr Zahawi calling for an inquiry on the matter. has contacted No for comment. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

title: cyclists told ride middle road
story: Cyclists told to ride in the middle of road in major Highway Code shake-upA major shake-up to the Highway Codes come in to force later this month, and people face a £ finethey dont follow the new rules £ - with cyclists facing the biggest alternationsMany are concerned about the changes Image: Getty ImagesByEmma MunbodhMoney EditorZoe ForseyFeatures Editor:,  Jan | commentsCyclists are being advised to ride in the middle of the road in some situations as part of a huge shake-up to the Highway Code. Riders will be advised to take the new position instead of the left-hand side of the lane when approaching junctions and on quiet roads. This rule remains in place eventhere is a cycle lane, which they are not obliged to use. The rules favour cyclists and pedestrians over drivers in a new hierarchy of road users, with the logic that they are the ones who can cause the least harm. But critics have warned the changes, which come into affect at the end of the month pending final approval, could cause accidents and tension between drivers and cyclists. Another new rule stats that drivers must leave at least . metres when overtaking cyclists. The positioning of cyclists is just one of many new changes announced by the Department of Transport, with those who donapost follow the rules facing tougher £ fines and six points for motorists.Bosses at road safety charity IAM RoadSmart are concerned the changes could cause an increase of road rage. Director of policy and research Neil Greig told The Times: A lot of drivers are going to think that somebody cycling in the middle of the lane in front of them is doing it to deliberately slow them down. That leads to conflict and road rage and inappropriate overtaking. Everybody needs to know all of these changes at the same time for it to work. The Highway Code shake-up will also see a change to how drivers use roundabouts, and for the first time the law will require those who can do the greatest harm to others to have a higher level of responsibility to reduce the danger. Rule  under the new section says people on the road will need to give priority to cyclists at roundabouts - Bristol Live reports.It states: You should give priority to cyclists on the roundabout. They will be travelling more slowly than motorised traffic. Give them plenty of room and do not attempt to overtake them within their lane. Allow them to move across your path as they travel around the roundabout. Cyclists, horse riders and horse drawn vehicles may stay in the left-hand lane when they intend to continue across or around the roundabout and should signal right to show you they are not leaving the roundabout. Drivers should take extra care when entering a roundabout to ensure that they do not cut across cyclists, horse riders or horse drawn vehicles in the left-hand lane, who are continuing around the roundabout.  It is a driveraposs responsibility to remain up-to-date with changes to the Highway Code, but the AA found in a survey last month that only a third of motorists were aware of the amendment.Charity campaigners have issued a warning to the government the new rules have not been promoted widely enough. Cycling UKaposs Duncan Dollimore said: Many people wonapost have read the Highway Code for years so itaposs essential that the key changes are clearly explained, with simple, accurate and memorable messages.A DfT spokesman said: The proposed upcoming changes to the Highway Code will improve safety for cyclists, pedestrians and horse riders and were announced to national press.The department has established a working group of key organisations to ensure that messages about the changes are as widespread as possible and our well-established Think! campaign will continue to ensure all road users are aware both when these changes come into effect and beyond. title: four schoolgirls aged 13 17
story: Four schoolgirls aged  to  sexually assaulted in  month as police hunt attackerThe four girls were all targeted in Greenwich, south east London, between December  and January  and police searching for the attacker have released a photo of someone they want to talk toPolice have released a photo of a man they want to speak to in relation to the assaults Image: Met PoliceBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Police hunting a man after four schoolgirls were sexually assaulted have released a photo of a person they want to speak to. The victims, aged between  and , were all targeted in Greenwich, south east London, inside a month.The force launched an urgent hunt after the youngsters all came forward to report the attacks. Three of the assaults took place within just six days of each other in the middle of January, the Met say. Detectives believe the offences may be linked and have asked anyone with information to come forward.  The first incident took place on December  when a -year-old child was followed after getting off a bus in on Hoveton Road. The man sexually touched her before running away when the victim screamed, police say. Three more attacks took place in mid-January. A police statement added: On Wednesday,  January, a -year-old girl was walking down Poplar Place, SE when she was approached by a man asking for directions. He pushed her against a fence and sexually touched her before she screamed and was able to run away.  On Thursday,  January, a -year-old girl was followed off the  bus by a man at Artillery Place, SE. He followed her into a nearby property and grabbed the back of her leg, causing her to fall. As she was on the floor he sexually touched her and ran from the scene when the victim shouted for help. On Tuesday,  January, a -year-old girl was walking down Kentlea Road, SE, when she was approached by a man who asked for directions. As she attempted to walk away, he sexually touched her before she was able to escape. DS James Robinson, who is leading the investigation, has asked anyone with information to make themselves known. “We know these incidents will cause concern within the community and we are doing all we can to identy the person responsible, he said. “We are also asking for your help –you recognise the man in this image or have any information that could assist us, no matter how small, then contact us as soon as possible.” Anyone with information should call  with CAD reference  JAN or Crimestoppers  per cent anonymously on   .
