title: cop president alok sharma urge countries act glasgow agreement
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAddressing stakeholders, business leaders and reporters at Chatham House in central London at around midday on Monday, the Cop President is due to encourage countries to work together on their commitments.Through the Glasgow Climate Pact signed in November,  countries agreed to strengthen their emissions-cutting targets for  by the end of next year in an attempt to limit global warming climbing above .C.Join @AlokSharma_RDG, #COP President at our upcoming members event  hear Mr Sharma reflect on the success of the Glasgow summit  set out the UK’s priorities for the rest of its Presidency #CHEvents📅  Jan⏰ : – :📍 HybridRegister gt https:t.co vmtxPOsvh pic XquXQsGc— Chatham House EventsJanuary , Negotiators also agreed to the weaker commitment of “phasing down” the use of coal after China and India declined to agree to it being “phased out” completely.Mr Sharma is expected to say: “There is no doubt that the commitments we secured at Cop were historic.“Yet at the moment they are just words on a page. And unless we honour the promises made, to turn the commitments in the Glasgow Climate Pact into action, they will wither on the vine.“We will have mitigated no risks. Seized no opportunities. We will have fractured the trust built between nations. And . degrees will slip from our grasp.“So my absolute focus for the UK Presidency year is delivery.”The cabinet minister recently visited the Cop President, Egypt, and Cop President UAE to underline the importance of building strong partnerships ahead of the next summits.He will also be meeting the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Changenext week to discuss implementation of the measures agreed in Glasgow..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Cop President Alok Sharma to urge countries to act on Glasgow agreement article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: payment schools support vaccination programme
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySpecial schools and alternative provision settings will also receive the one-off payment with an additional uplt based on pupil numbers, the Department for Educationsaid.The £ million in funding from NHS England will cover, for example, a member of support staff’s time on the day that in-school vaccination is taking place, as well as the time spent exchanging consent forms with parents and the NHS prior to the visit.The DfE said more than % of  to -year-olds – more than . million people – have now had at least one dose of the vaccine.Meanwhile, the Government has committed to delivering up to , air cleaning units to early years, schools and colleges to improve ventilation in classrooms.It confirmed it will be providing air cleaning units in response to all eligible applications and have bought an extra , units to do so.Since the Government launched its application process, , education settings have made valid applications to receive an air cleaning unit.Education Secretary Nadhim Zahawi said: “Face-to-face education for all students has consistently been my priority, and that is why I am pleased to further strengthen the tools available to schools to manage transmission of the virus, including funding air cleaning units for the small number of classrooms that need them due to poor ventilation, and providing additional NHS funding to free up staff time to engage with the vaccination programme for young people.“My message remains the same as ever – testing, ventilation and vaccinations are our best weapons against the virus – keep testing, and get your vaccination as soon as possible.”Nick Hulme, NHS vaccination lead for  to -year-olds, said: “The additional £ million in investment from the NHS will aim to further support schools to roll out the vaccine.“It is vitally important that families get their young ones protected – either in school, through an appointment booked online at a vaccine centre or at one of hundreds of walk-in sites.”.removeKevin Courtney, NEU joint general secretary, said: “We welcome all efforts to increase vaccine take up.“There has to be a real concern however that vaccination will not be enough or fast enough to stop the increasing disruption to education including of exam classes.“The Government should have invested in ventilation and air filtration before Omicron.“They should be working much harder to rollout these solutions now. The decision to remove facemasks may well prove to be very premature.”Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leaders’ union NAHT, said: “The news that there will be further air-cleaning devices made available for schools that need them is welcome.“We urge DfE to continue to monitor the situation carefully and ensure that every school that needs such a device receives one quickly.“The removal of other Covid measures in schools has made good ventilation more important than ever.“The additional payment to secondary schools to support the next stage of the vaccination programme is also welcome.“It’s important to note that it is the medical teams that will continue to be responsible for running the vaccination programme.“However, we learnt from the first round of vaccinations that schools do face some additional administrative burdens in supporting the medical teams and it is right that this has been acknowledged.”.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title:  xA, payment to schools to support vaccination programme article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: aldi launches bath products help pamper night
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityAnd we all know a pamper night is nothing without our favourite products.But be prepared to make some room on your shelf, because Aldi has introduced many new products to help you have the best pamper night that you’ll be sure to love.Vanilla Honey Golden Bath NectarThis bath honey has the most luxurious smell and texture. The comforting, sweet smell of honey paired with vanilla has your bath smelling like a spa.The texture is similar to honey, wrapped around a wooden honey stick, you hold the bath honey under the tap to create lovely, scented bubbles that fill the bath.This is one of many new products in Aldi’s luxury Lacura beauty brand including a new Korean beauty skincare range." alt"Penarth Times: " class"editor-image" If you haven’t yet discovered the powers of a Gua Sha then you’re missing out! A traditional Chinese medicine practice which uses a tool to massage and scrape your skin in order to relieve tension in the muscles of the face and encourage lymphatic drainage to get rid of any bloat.And you can now pick yours up at Aldi for only £.! You have the choice of Jade or Rose Quartz.CleanserFinish your night off with the Lacura Pineapple Hot Cloth Cleanser, a cleanser and toner enriched with pineapple extract, cocoa butter and aloe vera. title: co armagh mum of three hilary singleton delighted at obe for services to the ni community sector
story: Manwho was in in possession of heroin receives suspended jail sentence   Shooting at Portadown home of elderly woman is ‘deplorable’NewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleCo Armagh mum of three Hilary Singleton ‘delighted’ at OBE for services to the NI community sectorWith a long track record in public and community service, Hilary Singleton is ‘delighted’ that she was named in the Queen’s New Year’s Honours list for an OBE.By Carmel RobinsonSaturday, nd January , : am  "       "  The honour is for services to the community sector.Formerly from Coleraine and now living in Mullaghbrack near Markethill, Co Armagh, Hilary is a Board member of the International Fund for Ireland.Hilary grew up on the north coast, attended Coleraine High School and then studied Law at Queen’s University, Belfast, qualying as a solicitor in . She spent her legal career in private practice.Hilary Singleton OBE, originally from Coleraine and now living in Mullaghbrack, near Markethill, Co Armagh. Mrs Singleton was honoured with an OBE for services to the Community Sector in the Queens New Years Honours List.In , she was appointed by the Secretary of State for NI to the International Fund for Ireland, where she currently serves as a Board member. During her time with the IFI she influenced the development of innovative programmes and initiatives aimed at tackling some of the most dficult community issues within marginalised communities in NI and the border counties of Ireland.‘I am delighted at receiving this award which recognises the vital work in marginalised communities undertaken by the International Fund for Ireland. The award is a great honour and a wonderful way to start ’. It will be presented at Buckingham Palace on a date yet to be confirmed.Hilary currently also serves as a member of the Local Government Staff Commission and, last year, was appointed to the Board of the NI Fire and Rescue Service. She is a former Deputy Chair of the Health and Safety Executive of NI and a former Board member of the Ulster-Scots Agency, where she chaired the Agency’s Education and Audit and Risk Committees.In , she became Chair of the Southern Zone Steering Group of the Social Investment Fund whose Strategic Area Plan for the Zone addressed key issues of social and economic deprivation and employability and brought signicant investment from the NI Executive to the area.In December , she was appointed by the First and Deputy First Ministers to the Compact Civic Advisory Panel.She is a former Governor of Markethill High School and has been a Director of Mid-Armagh Community Network for many years.Hilary is married to Lewis, a solicitor, and has three children - William, Joanna and Jonathan. title: geolin takes the plunge to raise much needed funds for dog charity
story: Newtownabbey woman kicked driver on head causing police car to swerve at mph   Girl assaulted in Lurgan after being chased and grabbed by womanNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleGeolin takes the plunge to raise much needed funds for dog charityLisburn woman Geolin Walsh is braving the icy waters and taking the plunge to raise money for Lucy’s Trust, an animal charity close to her heart,By Julie-Ann SpenceSunday, rd January , : am  "       "  Geolin Walsh takes the plunge for charityGeolin only recently started open water swimming but has loved it so much that she decided to use her new found passion to fund one of her other passions, animal welfare, by supporting the local charity Lucy’s Trust.“I attended a natural resilience course last March, run by a guy called Ciaran May,” explained Geolin. “Part of this course was a cold water emersion in the sea, amongst other scary stuff.“I very nearly let that put me off, as i wasn’t a great swimmer, hadn’t swam in many year in a pool let alone the sea, and I had a fear of open water. I am not very body confident and the thought of putting on a swim suit horried me, and getting changed afterwards as well.”One of the dogs being looked after by Lucys TrustHowever, despite her fears, Geolin decided to be brave and take the plunge. “I wanted to challenge myself and thoughtI was going too do it I wanted to do it properly and learn how too swim in the sea,” she continued. “I looked for an open water swimming coach and Colin Mccard came very highly recommended.“I had my first lesson last April. It was freezing, I got cramp, I was terried, but, I loved it and have been taking open sea swimming lessons ever since. It took weeks too overcome my fears of being out of my depth, and actually learning how to swim, especially putting my face in the water, but it was all possible with the patience of a fantastic coach Colin. I feel ready to swim a distance and hopefully raise as much money as I can for the charity I volunteer at Lucy’s Trust.”Run by Olivia Kenned, who is a veterinary surgeon, and her partner Rob Durston, Lucy’s Trust, which is based near Lisburn, is a sanctuary for dogs who cannot be rehomed due to behavioural issues, or those that are in most need of a rescue place, and or assistance to overcome their dficulties to become happy healthy dogs once again.“This past two years has seen a signicant rise in the number of dogs Lucy’s Trust have been asked to take in with behavioural problems,” explained Geolin. “I am deeply saddened in the knowledge that many of these dogs are being put to sleep, young healthy dogs, who with the right commitment and guidance from their s could have gone on to live happy lives. This is not the fault of our struggling animal rescues, who can only take in the numbers they can actively care for.“Every rescue that I know of has been inundated with dogs in the last year. The current developing situation can only be referred to as a crisis. As a country we are failing our dogs on an unprecedented level, and I are really urging the general public to step up and take responsibility for the dog which they chose to procure. Please contact Lucy’s Trust for behavioural advice and recommendations for local positive reinforcement trainers who will help you to help your dog. Giving them up is not the answer, it is not a solution,”To help Lucy’s Trust continue their work, Geolin is planning to swim m- metres at Helen’s Bay. If you would like to support Geolin’s fundraising effort, visit https:gofund.me efd

title: recognition for commander of cullybackey college detachment acf
story: Manwho was in in possession of heroin receives suspended jail sentence   ‘Substantial’ sum of money found in PortadownNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleRecognition for Commander of Cullybackey College Detachment ACFLieutenant Stephen Lyons, Detachment Commander of Cullybackey College Detachment, Army Cadet Force has received The British Citizens Award, Certicate of Recognition.By Elinor GlynnSunday, rd January , : pm  "       "  Each year The British Citizen Award issue a limited number of Certicates of Recognition to people elevated into essential and key work.In more recent times the Award has looked to people who since the pandemic first struck, made great efforts and made a signicant impact during these unprecedented times.Lt Lyons joined the Army Cadet Force  years ago after a long career in the reserve army and has since changed the lives of many of his cadets and his certicate is as a result of the positive impact he and his Detachment made through their volunteering efforts.Lieutentant Stephen Lyons, who has received The British Citizen Award, Certicate of RecognitionDuring the pandemic, he was an inspiration for his community, organising assistance of the delivering of food parcels for Cullybackey Community Partnership, and distributing gts to isolated older people at Christmas amongst other local projects.This is not the only award Lt Lyons has received as on July   he had the honour of receiving the Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s daily Points of Light award and then the Lord Lieutenant’s Award in September from Her Majesty’s Lord-Lieutenant of County Antrim, Mr David McCorkell.At the time of becoming the th Point of Light, Lt Lyons said: "I feel extremely humbled to be recognised for my efforts by the Prime Ministers Office, especially at this time when so many people are volunteering to help others in such dficult times. I believe this represents all the hard work done by all those adults for young people in the Army Cadet Force."Colonel Adrian Donaldson, MBE, VR, DL, Commandant of the stBattalion Army Cadet Force said of Lt Lyons more recent award: “This is a well deserved award for Lt Stephen Lyons who is a exemplar for the ACF. He epitomises our adult volunteers and their commitment to provide the best possible experience for our youth, as we seek to develop them to their full potential. It follows closely on his personal ‘Points of light’ award from the Prime Minister, and is clear evidence of his dedication and hard work on behalf of all our cadets. Many congratulations and well done!”Lieutenant Stephen Lyons, Detachment Commander of Cullybackey College Detachment, Army Cadet Force has received The British Citizens AwardIf you are able to give up an evening a week and want to do something rewarding with your free time local to you, the Army Cadets could be exactly what you’re looking for.at www.armycadets  "       "  ]]Most Popular‘Substantial’ sum of money found in Portadown...NewsMan sent messages of sexual nature to girl...NewsWitnesses sought after car hits tree in M crash...NewsMaghera family raise a total of £, for health care facil...NewsBallymoney traffic disruption as police revisit scene of fat...NewsMost Popular                       This website and its associated newspaper are members of Independent Press Standards Organisation Follow us on    ExploreNewsSportWhats OnLestyleYour Northern IrelandRecommendedMore from Northern Ireland WorldAnnouncementsJobsPublic NoticesMust ReadBuy a PhotoNewspaper ArchiveUseful LinksContact UsAdvertise My BusinessArchiveSubscribeEventsPlace your AdReaders Charter " fill"#ea"  ©JPIMedia Publishing Ltd. ." target"_self" href"#" id"cookieSettings" class"sc-gsNilK sc-bXTejn cGeDpV iufVtK"Cookie SettingsTerms and ConditionsPrivacy policyModern Slavery Statement       " d"M.,.c-.-.-.-.-.-.c-.-.-.-.,-.c.-.,.-.,.,l.-. c.,.,.,.,.,c.-.,.-.,-.L,.c.,.,.,.,,.C.,.,.,.,.,." title: call for historic pension underpayments to be resolved
story: Manwho was in in possession of heroin receives suspended jail sentence   ‘Substantial’ sum of money found in PortadownNewsCoronavirusTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsHealthBusinessEducationPeopleEnvironmentRead ThisFootballIrish League FootballSportMotorcyclingIce HockeyOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoLestyleFood and DrinkTravelHomes and GardensCars FamilyYour NIRetroOpinionAdvertise My BusinessNewsPoliticsCall for historic pension underpayments to be resolvedSouth Tyrone Ulster Unionist MLA Rosemary Barton has said that the Department of Works  Pensions should inject urgency into resolving the underpayment to pensioners that had gone on for years.By Stanley CampbellSunday, rd January , : am  "       "  Mrs Barton said: “The DWP estimates it has underpaid , pensioners, mostly women, over £bn of their state pension entitlement, with some errors dating as far back as .“The long-term underpayment of state pensioners, an unknown number of whom will have died without receiving what they were owed, is disgraceful and requires urgent resolution.“Many people who were owed money from this process have since died, there doesn’t appear to be any provision as to how to deal with this situation for the families of loved ones that have passed away and were underpaid.”Rosemary Barton MLA.The Department for Work and Pensions are identying customers who have been underpaid State Pension in accordance with the law.If DWP identy you have been underpaid, they will let you know of the changes to your State Pension and any arrears due. title: take part in this year s big garden birdwatch
story: Keep your eyes wide open, get the kettle on and grab your binoculars as RSPB NI encourage you to join in on the charity’s Big Garden Birdwatch this month. That’s right, registration is now open for the world’s largest garden wildle survey taking place th- th January , and you don’t even have to leave your home to be part of it. RSPB NI is asking the public of Northern Ireland to spend just one hour watching and recording the birds in their garden, balcony or local park, then send their results to the RSPB. Over a million people took part in , counting  million birds – making it the biggest Birdwatch ever! By taking part in the Birdwatch, you will be helping to build an annual snapshot of how birdle is doing across the UK. It is only by understanding how wildle is faring that we can protect it. So, what are you waiting for  Take action to help solve the problems facing nature! To take part in the Big Garden Birdwatch  and receive your FREE Big Garden Birdwatch guide, which includes a bird identication chart, top tips for your birdwatch, plus advice on how to help you
